summary: This is a Department of Justice afternoon news digest from March 5, 2020, summarizing headlines and news articles across various topics. It includes a brief mention of a criminal investigation into potential misconduct by guards at the Metropolitan Correctional Center where Jeffrey Epstein died, and the jail's lockdown status.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased financier and accused sex trafficker
persons.context: Mentioned as the financier who killed himself at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, which is now under investigation for contraband and on lockdown.

persons.name: Bernard Madoff
persons.context: Prosecutors urged a judge to deny his early prison release from a 150-year sentence for his Ponzi scheme.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Mentioned as being poised to make an announcement on child sexual abuse online and as a speaker at the National Opioid Summit. Also noted for using certification power in immigration cases.

persons.name: Michael Horowitz
persons.context: Cited in a report finding FBI efforts to identify homegrown violent extremists fell short.

persons.name: Steve Williams
persons.context: Scheduled to speak at the DOJ's National Opioid Summit about partnerships with federal law enforcement.

persons.name: Mike Stuart
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for West Virginia's Southern District
persons.context: Coordinated Mayor Steve Williams's appearance at the National Opioid Summit.

persons.name: James Boasberg
persons.role: Chief Judge of the FISA court
persons.context: Wrote an opinion banning certain DOJ/FBI personnel from FISA work and invalidated Michigan Medicaid work requirements.

persons.name: Robert Mueller
persons.context: Cited in a report about Russian disinformation efforts during the 2016 elections.

persons.name: Mariam Taha Thompson
persons.context: Charged with espionage for allegedly passing classified information to a Lebanese man with Hezbollah ties.

persons.name: Friedrich Karl Berger
persons.context: Ordered to be removed from the United States after a trial.

persons.name: Mark Morgan
persons.role: Acting Customs and Border Protection Commissioner
persons.context: Announced that deportations now exceed border arrests.

persons.name: Chuck Schumer
persons.context: Expressed regret for remarks about Supreme Court Justices Gorsuch and Kavanaugh.

persons.name: John Roberts
persons.role: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
persons.context: Condemned Senator Schumer's comments as inappropriate and dangerous.

persons.name: Thomas B. Griffith
persons.role: Judge on the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals
persons.context: Announced retirement, giving President Trump another judicial appointment opportunity.

persons.name: R. Kelly
persons.context: Pleaded not guilty to an updated federal indictment including sex abuse allegations.

persons.name: Gary Jones
persons.context: Charged with embezzling more than $1 million of UAW funds.

persons.name: Donald McGahn
persons.context: A D.C. Circuit ruling found the House cannot sue to compel his testimony, affecting other House lawsuits.

persons.name: Letitia James
persons.context: Reaffirmed commitment to holding opioid makers accountable as a trial date was upheld.

events.title: DOJ Opens Investigation into MCC Contraband
events.description: The Justice Department opened a criminal investigation into potential misconduct by guards and the flow of contraband at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, where Jeffrey Epstein died.

events.title: MCC Lockdown
events.description: The Metropolitan Correctional Center had been on lockdown for six days in an effort to track down a smuggled gun, with inmates under 24-hour confinement.

events.title: Barr Announcement on Child Exploitation
events.description: Attorney General William Barr was poised to make an announcement, backed by leaders from four other countries, on DOJ efforts to address child sexual abuse online, unveiling voluntary principles for tech companies.

events.title: FISA Court Bans Certain Personnel
events.description: Chief Judge James Boasberg issued an opinion banning DOJ or FBI personnel under disciplinary or criminal review relating to FISA work from participating in FISA applications.

events.title: Prosecutors Oppose Madoff Early Release
events.description: Prosecutors urged a judge to deny Bernard Madoff's early release from prison, citing victim opposition and the magnitude of his Ponzi scheme.

locations: San Ysidro border crossing (near San Diego, CA)
keyFacts: The Justice Department opened a criminal investigation into potential guard misconduct and contraband flow at the Metropolitan Correctional Center where Jeffrey Epstein died.
The Metropolitan Correctional Center was on a six-day lockdown in an effort to locate a smuggled gun.
Attorney General William Barr was set to announce international efforts and voluntary principles for tech companies to combat child sexual exploitation online.
A FISA court opinion banned certain DOJ and FBI personnel under review from participating in FISA applications.
The news digest is a broad compilation of DOJ-related news from March 5, 2020, with only a few direct mentions of Epstein in the context of the jail investigation.
